abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project will support the three pillars of Guinea's
            poverty reduction strategy, and, cover the following
            reforms, designed to help improve public services,
            strengthen governance, and as a result, improve the
            environment for investment, and growth. The reforms aim to
            achieve: 1) more accountable, and efficient use of public
            resources, through improved public expenditure analysis, and
            management; 2) more effective government, through
            decentralization of decision-making, and service delivery;
            and, 3) improved public sector management, and more
            efficient resource use through divestiture. The successful
            implementation of the project will reinforce the
            Government's capacity to improve public service
            delivery, complement, and enhance the impact of other Bank
            interventions, and, contribute to restore credibility to
            public finances. However, risks affecting the reform program
            are the fragile security situation, significant shortfalls
            in revenue mobilization, which would threaten macroeconomic
            reforms, and, inadequate human, and institutional
            capacities, among others. Nonetheless, these risks are
            offset by the reestablishment of a credible macroeconomic
            environment, supported by strong political leadership, an
            Institutional Development Fund grant for governance, and
            integrity reforms to strengthen capacity, and, reforms in
            public sector management.
